cwe_description: The product converts a signed integer to an unsigned integer, but the signed integer has a negative value, which causes the unsigned integer to wrap around to a large positive value. This can lead to unexpected behavior, such as out-of-bounds array access or incorrect loop iterations.
explanation: The code retrieves an index as an 'int' from user input and then implicitly converts it to 'std::size_t'. If a negative integer is provided as input, it will be converted to a very large positive 'std::size_t' value due to signed-to-unsigned conversion rules. This large index is then used in 'buf->Peek(index, &tuple)', which can lead to an out-of-bounds read from the buffer, potentially causing a crash (denial of service) or information disclosure.

cwe_description: A signed-to-unsigned conversion error occurs when a signed integer is converted to an unsigned integer, and the signed integer has a negative value. This can result in an unexpectedly large positive value, which can then be used as an array index or size, leading to out-of-bounds access or buffer overflows.
explanation: The code reads an integer index from ctx->input(0) and implicitly converts it to std::size_t. If the input integer is negative, this conversion results in a very large positive std::size_t value. This large index is then used in buf->Peek(index, &tuple), which can lead to an out-of-bounds read from the buffer, potentially causing information disclosure or a denial of service.
